Jackal and the sun 
 Traditional San story 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Long ago, there was a folish lazy jackal.
 He lived with his old father in the
 
 Kalahari bush. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One morning Old Jackal woke up to find 
 his son sleping in the sun. The fod was 
 
 not ready and the goats were stil in the 
 kral! 
 
 
 “Young man, you are so lazy! Go and find 
 a wife. I am to old to lok after you,” 
 
 said Jackal’s father. So Jackal jumped up 
 and tok the goats out to graze. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 In the bush, he saw something shining
 on a rock. He went closer and closer to
 the rock. The closer he got, the more
 
 beautiful the shine was. Perhaps this
 was the wife for him?! 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “You are beautiful,” said Jackal to the 
 
 shine. “But who are you? Why are you 
 alone?” 
 “I am the sun,” the shine answered. “My 
 
 family left me here when they moved on. 
 They did not want to cary me. I am to 
 
 hot.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The jackal said, “But you are so beautiful!
 I wil cary you. I wil take you home to
 
 met my father.” 
 “Al right, you can cary me. But do not
 complain when I get to hot for you,” said
 
 the sun. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 So Jackal put the sun on his back and 
 started the journey home. Before long, 
 
 the sun was burning Jackal’s fur. 
 “Wil you please come down from my 
 back? I ned to rest,” said Jackal. His 
 
 back was so sore that he could hardly 
 walk. 
 
 “Just cary on!” said the sun. “I told you 
 not to complain!” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Then Jackal saw a log acros the path.
 He crawled under the log so that the sun
 
 would fal of. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 But the log also scraped the skin and fur 
 from his back and they were left behind 
 
 with the sun. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The new fur was a diferent colour to the
 fur on the rest of his body. 
 
 
 The diferent colours always reminded
 Jackal not to be so folish again.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 Story notes 
 In 205, Naro storyteler Bega Cgase from the Kalahari Desert in Botswana
 
 told this story to Marlene Winberg, who retels it here. The story apears in
 diferent versions in many southern African San comunities. It warns
 
 folish young men not to be confused by the outside apearance of a girl,
 and tels parents not to force their children to mary for the sake of
 domestic help. It also provokes the powerful presence of the hot sun in the
 
 desert and does what stories do – give everything in nature a personality.
 
 
 The ilustrations in this story are from story boards by Marlene Winberg,
 interpreted digitaly by Satsiri Winberg through manipulations of the
 Manyeka Art Colection of paintings made by San artists /Thalu Rumao,
 
 /Tuoi Samcuia and Joao Wene Dikuango, who have al pased away since.
